statement.p: Here is a topographic map showing part of Buck River and its surrounding area. Use this map to answer the questions below.

ol.li: A hiker walks (in a straight line) from point A to point B. Describe what happens to their elevation along the way. Be as specific as you can be.
What is the average rate of change in elevation when you walk from point C to point D? Show your work, and be sure to include units!
Does the Buck River flow north-to-south or south-to-north? Justify your answer (showing that you know how to read a contour map).
At point A, the hiker starts at 1500 ft. They walk uphill for about 4 miles, reaching about 1825 ft. Then they walk downhill for 2 miles until they return to 1500 ft at point B.
The AROC is (2000 ft - 1500 ft)/ (3 mi) = 500/3 ft/mi = 166.67 ft/mi.

The Buck River flows north-to-south because water flows downhill. As we travel north-to-south, the Buck River encounters contours at height 1400 ft, 1300 ft, 1200 ft, 1100 ft. So this must be the direction of flow.
